You missed out the reason they are called "compilers".  It was because it was assumed that the compiler would put together existing subroutines.  It was from the same means as to compile a dictionary.  The rate of real advancement of programming languages has slowed of late.  Mostly new languages are shuffling around existing ideas and in many cases copying old mistakes as though they were good ideas.  I will use an example:  If you want to deal with your location as one variable, you need to be able to hold 3 numbers in a variable rather than just one.  We usually call this sort of thing an array of numbers.  When the C language was created, they made it so that if you declared an array: int A[3]; What actually happened was a place in memory for 3 integers was allocated and "A" was made to be the location of the first element.  Thus you never really had an array variable but rather had a pointer to the array as your variable.  With simple variables "X=Y" would copy what is in Y into X.   With "B=A" for the arrays, you might expect 3 numbers to be copied but actually you would just end up with two pointers to the same location in memory.

The holy grail of programming languages is NOT the ability to use natural language! AppleTalk, anyone?  Is the holy grail of mathematics the ability to write proofs in natural language?  Humans always have difficulty with this concept... anytime anything is foreign or counterintuitive, obviously the problem is simply that it's foreign. But in reality, the difficulty of programming languages is that (usually) you're forced to be unambiguous, complete, precise, and explicit about what you mean and how you intend to manipulate information. People who aren't used to dealing with formal languages typically have real difficulty with this at first, because the human brain evolved to handle natural language, which is simply a different kind of tool. You get a good taste of things written with low-level programming with Apple computers (especially compared to the same computer running Bootcamp).
How's/Why that? Not nay saying just curious.

Mac computers have incredibly consistent hardware, so they can take advantage of compilers and coders writing things for specific architectures of hardware (either through directly working with the hardware or by using drivers or the like that are fewer layers of abstraction away from the hardware itself). This means that a Mac can easily handle some programs (like Photoshop, CAD programs, some games) on the Mac side, but they fail to perform on Bootcamp. Most don't get quite down to the metal, but they do work a good deal closer than general Windows programs can.  For example, if a Windows program were to want to display something to the screen, it would contact the OS which would then contact the graphics driver that would then contact the graphics card. A Mac program could either contact the driver itself or even contact the card. If it has to do processing on specialized tasks, this can speed things up and lead to less energy use.

Programs were also way more limited, ASM programming for simple 8 bit computers like Game Boy is orders of magnitude more simple than modern CPUs. You also don't have to worry about different hardware configurations which is now handled at software level.

Minastir1, the older programs weren't much more limited in what was possible (beyond speed and/or memory). It just has become more practical to go up a layer of abstraction or two and trust other programs to do a certain thing for you. However, the more abstraction there is, the more inefficiency there is. Also, with modern gaming consoles, they have consistent hardware configurations, which would make it at least possible, though not reasonable (thus the "crazy team with infinite resources").

You know that most Games for the PS3 and Xbox 360 got very low level near the end of those console's live time.  The problem is that modern computers aren't designed with ultra low level code in mind and complex tasks become near impossible to write.
The orginal Roller Coaster Tycoon was written "99% in Assembly" and 1% in C by Chris Sawyer.
@AlexPadula   Normal myths I've heard. This is most certainly not true.

Game developer here: AAA games studios are fairly close to "using 100% of the hardware". Computers are insanely fast, but games are also extremely complex, and we spend literal months researching and implementing performance improvements for a given title. That work is almost always re-used too. I.e. The engine we use (Unity) has thousands of programmers building off each others performance optimizations, and they're using the latest tech, and working closely with hardware manufacturers to utilize new developments. This is true of every large engine.   Example: A game running at 60 FPS means you have 16.67 milliseconds to do physics, gameplay logic, animation, audio, input processing, camera culling, rendering & shaders (which operate on each pixel), IO (reading/writing to disk), and network logic. You also need to give the OS time to do other things, and account for any instability (e.g. what happens if there is x2 more stuff to render on this frame).   I work on mobile games, and on our highest end devices, our game is roughly:  Input handling, gameplay & physics = 2 to 4ms Audio = 0.4ms Animation = 0.7ms Rendering - Culling (CPU) = 1 - 3ms Rendering - Other pipelining (CPU) = 3ms Rendering & Shaders (GPU) = 6-9ms Idle - The rest of the time.  Interestingly: Despite running smoothly at 60FPS, this amount of work is causing even our high end mobile devices to overheat. We are limited by battery life and device temperature, not by frame time. This is because modern mobile devices are designed for "burst" performance so they never hiccup. Annoyingly, some phone manufacturers don't even allow us to find out how hot they are getting (cough Apple cough), whereas others are providing API's that we can read from in-game to scale the game render quality down dynamically (Samsung, Google).  PC's and consoles are designed for sustained high CPU usage, so you should be able to use 100% of the 16.67ms safely (although some people will still crank things up too much and overheat their PC's).

Look at how often people misunderstand each other, especially on the internet. Natural languages are poor choices to convey specific intent, especially English. New words pop into existence, and old words fall in usage, so you'd have to keep updating the compilers to keep up. Some words only stay in existence for a little while, and their meaning is extremely culturally tied ("fleek" is a good example). You need a more formal specification. Also, a lot of programming is pretty math-heavy, and it's really cumbersome to convey mathematical concepts in natural languages. Programs would probably get significantly longer as well.  For example, here's some Javascript:  [1,2,3].reduce((total, value) => total + Math.pow(value, 2), 0);  Now here's the same thing in English:  "For a list containing one, two and three, compress them into a single value by going through each number of the list and adding its square to a total whose initial value is zero."  You can see how much more cumbersome the English is, and I'm not sure its meaning has even really been conveyed, even to a a person whose first language is English. Whereas, the Javascript can be understood by anyone who has taken the time to learn it. So, for making programs, we need a more formal language. Contemporary programming languages succeed in this to varying degrees, and I imagine they'll get a lot better, but they will probably never look like a natural language.

She skipped over that bit because assembler is machine specific and requires hardware programming. Naming doesn't help anything here. The language (what you write) is called "Assembly". The (hardware) program you use to create the machine code (binary) is called "Assembler". In the assembling process the symbolic names like "LOAD_A" are transformed directly into the operate code. After that process you then execute the machine code to do whatever it is that you actually wrote.  Wikipedia should actually be pretty helpful here. Look up "Assembly Language". For deeper understanding of the programs to write other programs, look up the "Software Development" section of the "Bootstrapping" Wikipedia page.

Mike Meyer   Making a correction - good explanation on LoneTech 's part.  Compilation involves a conversion to another language (ie., assembler) - the output of which is then run either on bare-metal or a VM. Interpretation involves executing the code line-by-line, usually by another program.

Machine code being the target is not what defines a compiler, nor is the absence of a runtime (most compiled languages do use runtimes, some can be used without). The key is in the translation output. An interpreter will read your code and perform the actions described itself, while a compiler will read the code and output translated code in another language. That language may be machine code, which would make assemblers also be compilers, but for most compilers it's another, intermediate representation. Clear examples are assembler, LLVM, SPIR-V, JVM, CIL or CPython's bytecode. The distinctive mark of assemblers is the direct correlation with machine instructions, but with things like macro assemblers and compiled languages close to specific machines even those lines blur.   No directly interpreted implementation of Python comes to mind. CPython, IronPython, MicroPython and Jython all compile to different virtual machines. Cython and Pyjs compile to other languages. PyPy actually does compile to native code, albeit with a high level of abstraction from the data semantics. https://wiki.python.org/moin/PythonImplementations lists quite a few others, perhaps some of them do direct interpretation. Whether done Just In Time (which PyPy does) or Ahead Of Time, compilation of Python is the norm (and the compiler is in the standard library). The target being an interpreting runtime is also the norm. Ahead of time compilation of Python to standalone native code is not, however. Note that standalone itself is another nebulous criterion; most languages require some portion of runtime support in another language on most machines, and most programs run in an operating system. C runtimes are still written in assembly, if only to set up the call to main.   Python is a language that has traditionally interpreter-bound semantics and multilayered implementations. The lines between compiled and interpreted languages have blurred as either form of processing is possible for many languages; to some extent it is now more about how dynamic the semantics are, with possible introspection and self-modification, and Python is highly dynamic but does not typically process code objects themselves beyond generating them with the compiler and calling them. Some languages (for instance Nim) wrap the concepts the other way around, running interpreters within the compiler and outputting static code. Any machine code can be interpreted in a simulator, quite a few of which do JIT compile.   Stating that Cython is interpreted is incorrect; it is no more interpreted than a C-written extension module for CPython (though it has passed through one more compiler), or an assembler subroutine called from C code. It links with CPython's runtime and does not pass through the interpreter, which reads CPython bytecode. The distinction here is in portions of CPython; it contains a compiler, a bytecode interpreter, a Python library, a C runtime support library and a CPython module library. Cython code runs as part of the interpretation, adding to the CPython library. The program as a whole normally is interpreted as the Python code calling the Cython module is. For a comparison, consider the Firefox web browser. Would you call the entire program interpreted because its UI is partially controlled by Javascript code?   In the end, Python here only acts as a poor example if you're already knowledgeable enough to not need the example. It was likely chosen because it doesn't require other noise around the code, and is easily available to learn and use. Consider it like the use of Newtonian physics; the approximation works.

So instead of asking the computer to do specific things, it'd be more like: "There is a concept called a User. The system has many Users that are unique. You should check out Lisp then. It makes metaprogramming easier than regular programming in many cases, since you can use syntactic macros to extend the language itself within your program.  For example, it doesn't have a C-like for loop built in, but if you want to have one you can make one yourself by defining a macro.  A common way to solve programs in Lisp is to define your own domain specific language for any particular task, since the language makes this easy enough that it actually becomes a practical way to solve many problems.

In a programming language like Haskell we deal with abstractions of abstractions of abstractions. For example, you can have a value, and you can have a list of values. A list on its own does not mean anything, you have to have a list of something. But we can talk about an abstraction of a list, like we can loop over it, or we can take off the first item without knowing what is in the list. In the same way, we can talk about things that can be looped over, or more generally, things that can be mapped over. It turns out you can map over state, IO operations, trees, lists, and many things you would not expect. This is a giant rabbit hole, or more accurately an abstraction of a rabbit hole.

Alright. So yes, the industry programs in C/C++ most of the time, but it's not because people enjoy it. I code in C/C++ as well and I personally dislike the language. C++ especially has a problem that originated from its design philosophy, that code written 30 years from now should still be valid code. What this means is that throughout its history very few features have ever been deprecated, and when new functionality is added into the language it either becomes syntactically ambiguous or is wrapped inside of confusing namespaces structs or classes. For example std::unique_ptr<type>, it's a template type that helps with managing pointers and ensuring that you don't leave hanging pointers and etc. It helps with preventing memory leaks or managing memory. The problem is that the type is unique_ptr and the template type is the actual data type, the uniqueness of the pointer is the type and the actual type is a parameter of it. Most modern languages that have unique pointers have the uniqueness be an attribute of the variable instead, which makes far more sense both from a syntactical point of view and from a logic point of view. To make a variable owned someone simply needs to add a single syntactical change, to change the ownership of a unique_ptr you need to remove the unique_ptr the angled brackets, and then you need to actually make the object a pointer. That's a lot of changes to change a single attribute of the object. Talk to most people who have worked with C++ for several years and they will almost all tell you they don't like the language. The reason it's still the industry standard in many fields is simply because of the overwhelming cost to recode old infrastructure. You have millions of lines of code, or billions, that would need to be converted, you'd need to recode entire collections of libraries, etc, you'd then need all consumers to then download and use the new version.  Most people who know C++ and D say that switching to D would make the work environment have less friction , but that D is too similar to C++ *although without the legacy stuff that makes C++ bloated) and doesn't have any revolutionary feature that really makes switching practical. It would just take a very, very large amount of work to switch over, and because of this people tend to prefer staying with C/C++ even though many people don't like it, and are liking it less every update.  For me D just has some nice syntactical differences. One thing it doesn't have is headers. Headers are left over from years ago when compilers were less powerful and the linker needed to be fed more information about expected symbols. Nowadays modern compilers for modern languages can generate the equivalent of headers automatically, eliminating the need for using such a feature at all. Like C++ D does not need to be object orientated, you can just as easily run procedural code as object oriented code, however D have a more complete implementation of common OOP paradigms and concepts. D is similar to C/C++ in many ways, just without the bloat and legacy features and with cleaner syntax. It also combines C/C++ features with features from other more abstract languages like Python, Java, etc, only does them in a compiled program.  D's main problem is the lack of use. The lack of people using it leads to lack of libraries made for it, it also leads to less support smaller support communities, which leads to less documentation, and all of this leads to less people using the program and it's a continuous cycle. The other problem is that periodically D does change, unlike C/C++ D is not afraid to throw out old stuff that doesn't work like it should. almost all of these times the changes won't affect much code because the details that are changed are parts of the standard library which is hidden behind some abstraction, but for certain users who wish to get certain benefits out of a system these changes require you to test your programs efficiency and accuracy again and potentially change, which isn't that great for businesses.  +Mike Meyer that is false. First off, SQL is not a programming language, it's a query language, which is very different, secondly no, it's not the most popular. SQL or Structured Query Language is used exclusively to pull information out of databases, it is NOT used for general computing and in-fact is barely even Turing Complete without any extensions. C/C++ is the industry standard language for high-performance programs. Java and Python are also extremely popular languages for general computing. It is true that SQL is a language (not PROGRAMMING language, but language in general) that is one of the most in-demand in the industry, but do not for a single second think that means most popular, most used, most powerful, most useful, fastest or best programming language, because as I've stated several times, it's not a programming language, it's a query language, secondly it's fairly slow, it's bulky to use, etc. You really need to learn the difference between programming languages, scripting languages, query languages, markup languages, etc... They're all different.

There are hundreds of different ways to measure popularity. However none of them rank SQL at the top. The TIOBE index ranks PL/SQL at #19 with 1.676% rating versus 14.639 for Java,7.002% for C and 4.751% for C++ (based on a combination of factors ). The PYPL index doesn't even rank SQL in the top 22, Java gets 22.7% rating, Python gets 15.7% rating, PHP gets 9.3% (base on Google Trends reflecting search rates for languages). The RedMonk Programming Language Rankings doesn't have SQL in the top 20, with Javascript, Java and Python as the most popular languages (based on GitHub usage and StackOverflow questions), Indeed ranked Java as having more job offerings posted than the other languages combined,  a poll by StackOverflow showed that 55% of the developers on that site use JavaScript (not exclusively), IEEE's Spectrum rankings for programming languages ranks C, Java, Python and C++ as the top 4 popular languages (based on several factors. They have an interactive listing where you can adjust the weights of each metric to tune the ratings to your like. but only two of those metrics rank SQL in the top 10, Career Builder ranks SQL #2 in jobs offerings, and Dice is the only metric that ranks SQL #1 in job offerings). SQL is a common skill that employers want you to know, but in terms of how often it's used relative to other languages that are used for general purpose computing, it ranks very low.
